titleStmt.title: Compilation of the Works of Christine de Pizan (Manuscrit du Duc, Vol. III)

note.p: Français 836, Bibliothéque national de France, Paris. Paris, ca. 1406-1408.
Ivory parchment with dark spots, small holes, some stitches, flies, and numerous pieces, most quite large, carefully incorporated in the manuscript, especially at the lower edge.
(IV, paper) + 98 + (IV, paper).Modern foliation appears on the top right corner of the manuscript in red ink.

Visible light gray ruling marks, probably done with a very hard lead pencil, which left frequent ridges. Some folios do not have any visible ruling, which might indicate the use of dry pencil. There is also visible pricking on the bottom margin with two or four pricks (circular and elliptical).
The mise-en-page for the text, in verse, has 2 columns with 42 lines each (although sometimes they can be 39, 40 or 41). Each column measures around 48,5 mm.

Almost all the text is written in dark brown ink, with bright red ink and orange red being used for the rubrics. There seems to be a main scribal hand (R) for the text, and two other hands (E and P) for some corrections and some of the bright red rubrics. The main text has been written using a semi cursive minuscule script. There are signs of punctuation. The scribe (R) uses commas and periods. Very discreet scansion bars mark the decasyllabic verses. There are some corrections in the text done mainly by R, and some by P, by scratching the parchment. Furthermore, there are several extant preparations for corrections written in a quick cursive script (hand P?).

There are five large foliated initials (fols. 1, 42, 48, 63, 65) either in pink or blue over a gold leaf background with foliate extenders and "sperm" coming out of the top and bottom of the left side of the initials. These foliate extenders partially frame the miniature above and the text below the initials. There are many other smaller foliated initials in pink and blue over a gold leaf background in the manuscript with gold leaf foliate extenders also framing the text and other miniatures.

There are eighteen miniatures. The first ten miniatures were created by the Master of l'Épître Othéa (ff. 1, 3, 5, 10, 12, 15, 19, 40, 42, 45) and the last eight by the Master of Egerton (ff. 48, 63, 65, 66, 71, 74, 76). All the illustrations are framed with a fine line of gold leaf outlined in black, and coming from the frame are gold leaf foliate extenders alternating with gold leaf "sperm".

note.p: The original binding was made of wood covered with black silk. The inventory of the library of the Bourbon in the castle of Moulins reported that the binding was done in 1523: " couver[t] de veloux rouge et tenné garny [...] de fermans de leton, de boulhons et carrées." It was replaced in the early 19th century with the current calf binding with a marbled festoon gilded back, with 5 nerves, dated to the 20th century. There are also traces of gilding and carving.

Created circa 1406-1408, the manuscript constitutes the third volume of the compilation of the works of Christine de Pizan acquired by the Duke of Berry in 1408. It was very likely intended for Louis d'Orleans before his death on November 23rd, 1407.

Provenance: Jean de Berry, his daughter Marie de Berry, duchess of Bourbon; François I, who seized the property of the constable Charles of Bourbon in 1523. Old shelfmarks: 862 (Dupuy); 7216 (Regius).
